This chapter is a continuation of the previous one, detailing the goatherds' hospitality and Antonio's song. It also contains Don Quixote's discourse on the Golden Age.

**Chapter XII: Of What a Goatherd Related to Those with Don Quixote**
A young goatherd brings news of the death of Chrysostom, a student-shepherd, who died of love for the beautiful shepherdess Marcela. Chrysostom's will directs him to be buried in the fields where he first saw Marcela. His friend Ambrosio insists on fulfilling the will, despite the clergy's objections. Don Quixote learns about Chrysostom's wealth and learning, and Marcela's beauty and independent life as a shepherdess, rejecting all suitors. Don Quixote resolves to attend the burial.

**Chapter XIII: In Which is Ended the Story of the Shepherdess Marcela, with Other Incidents**
Don Quixote and Sancho, along with the goatherds and some travelers (including Vivaldo), journey to Chrysostom's burial site. Don Quixote explains knight-errantry to Vivaldo, who, realizing Don Quixote is mad, encourages him to speak. Don Quixote describes Dulcinea's superhuman beauty and noble lineage, though Sancho internally notes her real identity as Aldonza Lorenzo. At the burial, Ambrosio laments Chrysostom's unrequited love for Marcela and intends to burn his papers. Vivaldo persuades him to save some. Vivaldo reads Chrysostom's "Lay of Despair." Marcela appears and defends her right to live freely and not be blamed for Chrysostom's death. Don Quixote, impressed, declares that no one should follow her. The burial proceeds, and Don Quixote resolves to seek Marcela.

**Chapter XIV: Wherein are Inserted the Despairing Verses of the Dead Shepherd, Together with Other Incidents Not Looked For**
This chapter provides the full text of Chrysostom's "Lay of Despair," followed by Ambrosio's explanation of its context. Marcela's appearance and her eloquent defense of her freedom and innocence are detailed. Don Quixote's subsequent declaration protecting Marcela from pursuit is also included. The chapter ends with the burial of Chrysostom and the departure of the various parties, with Don Quixote resolving to seek Marcela.

**Chapter XV: In Which is Related the Unfortunate Adventure That Don Quixote Fell in With When He Fell Out With Certain Heartless Yanguesans**
Don Quixote and Sancho search for Marcela in the woods. Rocinante attempts to mate with some Yanguesan carriers' ponies and is beaten. Don Quixote and Sancho intervene, fighting the numerous carriers and are severely beaten. Don Quixote blames his misfortune on fighting non-knights and the Sage Friston. He promises Sancho the balsam of Fierabras. Sancho complains about the pain and the impracticality of knight-errantry. Don Quixote defends his calling. Sancho discovers his saddle-bags are missing. They find an inn, which Don Quixote insists is a castle.

**Chapter XVI: Of What Happened to the Ingenious Gentleman in the Inn Which He Took to Be a Castle**
At the inn, Don Quixote is given a poor bed. The innkeeper's wife, daughter, and the Asturian servant Maritornes attend to his wounds. Sancho explains knight-errantry to Maritornes. Don Quixote, mistaking the inn for a castle and Maritornes for the lord's daughter, believes she is in love with him. Maritornes, intending to meet the carrier, accidentally encounters Don Quixote. He grasps her, praises her beauty, and declares his fidelity to Dulcinea. The jealous carrier punches Don Quixote, and a chaotic brawl ensues in the dark, involving Sancho, Maritornes, and the innkeeper. An officer of the Holy Brotherhood enters, assuming Don Quixote is dead.

**Chapter XVII: In Which are Contained the Innumerable Troubles Which the Brave Don Quixote and His Good Squire Sancho Panza Endured in the Inn, Which to His Misfortune He Took to Be a Castle**
Don Quixote recovers and believes the inn is enchanted. He tells Sancho that a giant (the enchanted Moor) attacked him. Sancho, who was also beaten, is skeptical. The officer, lighting a lamp, strikes Don Quixote on the head. Don Quixote, bleeding, asks for balsam ingredients. Sancho fetches them. Don Quixote prepares the balsam, drinks it, vomits, and then feels cured. Sancho drinks the rest, suffers terribly, and curses it. Don Quixote attributes Sancho's suffering to his not being a knight.

Don Quixote, feeling well, prepares to leave. The innkeeper demands payment. Don Quixote, still believing it a castle, refuses to pay. He rides off. Sancho also refuses to pay, citing knight-errant custom. The inn's guests seize Sancho and blanket him. Don Quixote, hearing his cries, returns but cannot intervene due to his injuries. Sancho is eventually released. He drinks wine (not balsam) and leaves, having paid nothing, though the innkeeper keeps his saddle-bags.

**Chapter XVIII: In Which is Related the Discourse Sancho Panza Held with His Master, Don Quixote, and Other Adventures Worth Relating**
Sancho, bruised, rejoins Don Quixote, who still believes the inn was enchanted. Sancho insists the attackers were real people. Sancho suggests they return home, but Don Quixote dismisses this, extolling the life of a knight-errant. Sancho complains about their lack of real victories. Don Quixote promises a magic sword. They see dust clouds, which Don Quixote believes are two armies. He identifies the leaders: Emperor Alifanfaron and King Pentapolin of the Bare Arm. Sancho sees only sheep. Don Quixote, convinced by his delusion, charges the flock, spearing several sheep. The shepherds stone him, breaking his ribs and smashing his balsam flask. Don Quixote blames the enchanter Friston. He vomits balsam onto Sancho. Sancho, disgusted, vomits back. Sancho discovers his saddle-bags are lost. Don Quixote consoles him with philosophical remarks about fortune. Sancho complains about his missing teeth. Don Quixote laments his lost teeth but accepts it as part of chivalry.

**Chapter XIX: Of the Shrewd Discourse Which Sancho Held with His Master, and of the Adventure That Befell Him with a Dead Body, Together with Other Notable Occurrences**
Sancho attributes their misfortunes to Don Quixote's broken oath. Don Quixote agrees to make amends. They travel at night, hungry and without provisions. They encounter a procession of "encamisados" (men in white shrouds) with torches, accompanying a black-covered litter. Don Quixote believes it's a knight being carried away and attacks them. He wounds one man, who reveals they are priests transporting a dead body. Don Quixote apologizes, explaining he mistook them for evil spirits. Sancho, meanwhile, plunders the provisions from one of their mules. Don Quixote asks Sancho why he called him "Knight of the Rueful Countenance," and Sancho explains it's due to his master's gaunt appearance. Don Quixote adopts the name and plans to paint it on his shield. They retreat to a valley and eat Sancho's stolen provisions.

**Chapter XX: Of the Unexampled and Unheard-of Adventure Which Was Achieved by the Valiant Don Quixote of La Mancha with Less Peril Than Any Ever Achieved by Any Famous Knight in the World**
Sancho suggests finding water. They hear the sound of falling water and a rhythmic hammering. Don Quixote believes it's a perilous adventure and delivers a grand speech, comparing himself to Amadis of Gaul and Roland. He instructs Sancho to wait three days, and if he doesn't return, to tell Dulcinea he died for her. Sancho, weeping, tries to dissuade him, then ties Rocinante's legs to prevent his departure. Don Quixote, believing it enchantment, agrees to wait for dawn. Sancho tells a long, rambling story about a goatherd and 300 goats, which ends when Don Quixote loses count. Sancho then quietly relieves himself, and Don Quixote, smelling him, attributes it to Sancho's fear. At dawn, Sancho unties Rocinante. Don Quixote, seeing Rocinante move, takes it as a sign. They discover the noise comes from six fulling hammers. Don Quixote is mortified, and Sancho laughs, earning a beating from his master. Don Quixote justifies his actions, blaming enchanters for disguising the hammers. He reminds Sancho of the master-servant hierarchy.

**Chapter XXI: Which Treats of the Exalted Adventure and Rich Prize of Mambrino’s Helmet, Together with Other Things That Happened to Our Invincible Knight**
Don Quixote and Sancho encounter a barber wearing a brass basin on his head to shield from rain. Don Quixote believes it is Mambrino's helmet and charges the barber, who flees, leaving the basin. Don Quixote claims it as his prize, despite Sancho recognizing it as a basin. Don Quixote attributes its appearance to enchanters. Sancho, having found gold crowns in a valise earlier, is now content. Sancho suggests they serve an emperor to gain fame and wealth. Don Quixote agrees, envisioning himself marrying a princess and making Sancho a count. Don Quixote advises Sancho to shave his beard to appear more refined.

**Chapter XXII: Of the Freedom Don Quixote Conferred on Several Unfortunates Who Against Their Will Were Being Carried Where They Had No Wish to Go**
Don Quixote and Sancho encounter a chain of galley slaves. Don Quixote, believing they are being taken by force, demands their release. He interrogates each slave about their crimes. Among them is Gines de Pasamonte, a notorious thief who has written his own life story. Don Quixote, despite Sancho's warnings, attacks the guards and frees the slaves. Don Quixote then orders the freed slaves to go to El Toboso and present themselves to Dulcinea. Gines de Pasamonte refuses, fearing the Holy Brotherhood. Don Quixote, enraged, threatens Gines, who then incites the other slaves to stone Don Quixote. They beat him, strip him of his jacket and the basin-helmet, and scatter. Don Quixote and Sancho are left battered and without their belongings.

**Chapter XXIII: Of What Befell Don Quixote in the Sierra Morena, Which Was One of the Rarest Adventures Related in This Veracious History**
Don Quixote, acknowledging Sancho's earlier warnings, agrees to retreat into the Sierra Morena to escape the Holy Brotherhood. While they sleep, Gines de Pasamonte, also hiding in the mountains, steals Dapple. Sancho wakes and laments the loss of his ass. Don Quixote consoles him, promising him three ass-colts. Don Quixote is delighted to be in the mountains, seeing them as a place for adventures. They find a valise containing fine linen and gold crowns. Don Quixote believes it belongs to a slain traveler. He finds a sonnet and a love letter in a notebook, revealing a story of unrequited love. He then sees a ragged, naked man leaping among the rocks, whom he believes is the owner. Don Quixote resolves to find him. Sancho, in a moment of pragmatism, suggests keeping the money. They encounter an old goatherd, who tells them about a well-bred youth who went mad after being betrayed in love, often attacking shepherds for food. The madman, Cardenio, appears. Don Quixote embraces him.

**Chapter XXIV: In Which is Continued the Adventure of the Sierra Morena**
Cardenio, after eating, agrees to tell his story without interruption. He recounts his love for Luscinda and their parents' approval. His friend Don Fernando becomes smitten with Luscinda after Cardenio shows her to him. Don Fernando, under the pretext of buying horses, sends Cardenio away. Cardenio receives a letter from Luscinda, revealing Don Fernando's treachery: he has demanded her hand in marriage, and her father has agreed. Luscinda plans to kill herself during the wedding. Don Quixote interrupts, praising Luscinda's love for chivalry books. Cardenio, in a mad fit, mentions "Queen Madasima," which enrages Don Quixote. Cardenio then attacks Don Quixote with a stone and beats Sancho and the goatherd before fleeing. Don Quixote, despite being beaten, still wants to hear the end of Cardenio's story.

**Chapter XXV: Which Treats of the Strange Things That Happened to the Stout Knight of La Mancha in the Sierra Morena, and of His Imitation of the Penance of Beltenebros**
Sancho, on foot, complains about the hardships and his inability to talk freely. Don Quixote lifts the interdict on his tongue. Sancho questions Don Quixote's defense of Queen Madasima. Don Quixote explains his plan to imitate Amadis of Gaul's penance on Peña Pobre, or Roland's madness, to prove his love for Dulcinea. Sancho, still pragmatic, calls Mambrino's helmet a barber's basin, which Don Quixote dismisses as enchantment. Don Quixote chooses a secluded spot for his penance. He releases Rocinante and delivers a lament to Dulcinea. Sancho, concerned about walking, suggests using Rocinante for his return journey. Don Quixote agrees to let Sancho leave after three days of observing his madness. Don Quixote plans to tear his clothes and hit his head on rocks. Sancho suggests softer alternatives. Don Quixote writes a letter to Dulcinea and an order for three ass-colts for Sancho. Sancho, after seeing Don Quixote strip and perform capers, is convinced he is mad and departs on Rocinante.

**Chapter XXVI: In Which are Continued the Refinements Wherewith Don Quixote Played the Part of a Lover in the Sierra Morena**
Don Quixote, alone, debates between Roland's and Amadis's madness, choosing Amadis's melancholy. He makes a rosary from his shirt and writes verses. Meanwhile, Sancho reaches the inn where he was blanketed. He encounters the curate and barber, who recognize him and Rocinante. Sancho, trying to keep Don Quixote's location secret, invents a story about his master doing penance and carrying a letter to Dulcinea (Aldonza Lorenzo). He realizes he lost the letter and the ass-colt order, and tears his beard in frustration. The curate promises to renew the order. Sancho recites the letter from memory, adding absurdities. The curate and barber decide to retrieve Don Quixote. Dorothea, overhearing, offers to disguise herself as a distressed damsel. Sancho is delighted, believing she is Princess Micomicona, and hopes Don Quixote will marry her to become emperor, making him a count. The curate and barber disguise themselves. They find Don Quixote, who is now clothed. Dorothea kneels before him, asking for a boon to avenge a giant who usurped her kingdom. Don Quixote grants it. Sancho, delighted, plans to sell the black vassals from the kingdom. The curate and Cardenio join them, the barber's beard falls off but is "magically" reattached. Don Quixote, the princess, and the curate ride, while Cardenio, the barber, and Sancho walk. Dorothea tells her (false) story of being Princess Micomicona, whose father King Tinacrio prophesied Don Quixote would defeat the giant Pandafilando and marry her. Sancho confirms Don Quixote's mole. Sancho is excited about becoming king. Altisidora, a duchess's handmaid, sings a love song for Don Quixote. Don Quixote rejects her, declaring his fidelity to Dulcinea. A prank involving bells and cats is played on Don Quixote, leaving his face scratched. Sancho is taken to a village, Barataria, to be governor. He makes several judgments, including discovering money in a cane and banishing a woman for ten years. He receives a letter from the duke warning of spies. Sancho replies to Don Quixote, complaining about the doctor and hunger. Doña Rodriguez complains to Don Quixote about a farmer who seduced her daughter. Don Quixote promises to help. A combat is arranged, but the lacquey Tosilos, disguised as the farmer, falls in love with the daughter and yields. Altisidora sings a farewell lament. Don Quixote is defeated by the Knight of the White Moon (Samson Carrasco) and forced to return home for a year.

**Part Two: Dedication and Preface**
The dedication to the Count of Lemos mentions the "Second Part" of Don Quixote and a "masquerading" version by another author. Cervantes states he is finishing "Trabajos de Persiles y Sigismunda."
The author's preface to the Second Part addresses the rival author. Cervantes defends himself against accusations of being old and one-handed, emphasizing the honor of his wounds from battle. He dismisses the rival's claim of envy and recounts two anecdotes about madmen and dogs, implying the rival's work is foolish. He states that his Second Part will show Don Quixote "continued, and at length dead and buried," to prevent further false continuations.

**Chapter I: Of the Interview the Curate and the Barber Had with Don Quixote About His Malady**
A month after Don Quixote's return, the curate and barber visit him, finding him withered but speaking rationally on various subjects, including statecraft. They believe he is cured. The curate tests him by mentioning the Turk's impending attack. Don Quixote suggests commanding all knights-errant in Spain to assemble to defeat the Turk. The niece fears he's relapsing. The barber recounts a story of a madman in Seville who believed himself cured, but then declared himself Jupiter, only to be contradicted by another madman claiming to be Neptune. Don Quixote dismisses the barber's story, asserting the reality of knights-errant and their power. He argues that chivalry is a religion, and there are sainted knights. Sancho adds that there are more friars than knights in heaven. They discuss the great city of El Toboso.

**Chapter II: Which Treats of the Notable Altercation Which Sancho Panza Had with Don Quixote’s Niece, and Housekeeper, Together with Other Droll Matters**
The niece and housekeeper try to prevent Sancho from seeing Don Quixote, accusing him of deluding their master. Sancho defends himself, claiming he is the one deluded and that he is still waiting for his promised island. He boasts of his future governorship. Don Quixote intervenes, allowing Sancho in. The curate and barber leave, despairing of Don Quixote's recovery. Don Quixote scolds Sancho for insulting the duenna and for his boorishness, reminding him that a master's reputation depends on his servant's conduct. Sancho promises to be more circumspect.

**Chapter III: Of the Laughable Conversation That Passed Between Don Quixote, Sancho Panza, and the Bachelor Samson Carrasco**
Don Quixote, pondering his history being in print, fears the author (Cide Hamete) is a Moor and might have misrepresented his love for Dulcinea. Sancho and the bachelor Samson Carrasco arrive. Carrasco, kneeling, praises Don Quixote and the history. Don Quixote learns his history is printed in thousands of volumes. Sancho points out an error: his wife's name is not Doña Dulcinea. They discuss the most famous adventures in the book, including the windmills, fulling mills, and galley slaves. Sancho asks if his drubbings are included. Carrasco confirms they are, including Sancho's blanketing. Don Quixote laments the inclusion of such undignified events. Carrasco explains the difference between a poet and a historian. Sancho complains about his own beatings. Carrasco mentions the author forgot who stole Dapple and what Sancho did with the hundred crowns. Sancho explains Dapple was stolen by Gines de Pasamonte and he spent the crowns on his family. Don Quixote asks if a second part is promised. Carrasco says it is, but the author hasn't found it. Sancho offers to provide more adventures. Carrasco advises Don Quixote to go to Saragossa for jousts. Sancho insists on fighting only when necessary. Don Quixote asks Carrasco to compose an acrostic poem for Dulcinea. Carrasco agrees, noting the difficulty of the 17-letter name.

**Chapter IV: In Which Sancho Panza Gives a Satisfactory Reply to the Doubts and Questions of the Bachelor Samson Carrasco, Together with Other Matters Worth Knowing and Telling**
Sancho explains Dapple's theft: Gines de Pasamonte stole him while Sancho slept, using a trick like Brunello's. He later recovered Dapple. Sancho justifies spending the hundred crowns on his family. Carrasco notes the author's error in mentioning Dapple before his recovery. Don Quixote asks about a second part. Carrasco says it's promised but not found, and some readers want more "Quixotades." Sancho offers to provide more adventures. Rocinante neighs, which Don Quixote takes as a good omen. Don Quixote decides to go to Saragossa for jousts. Carrasco advises caution. Sancho insists on Don Quixote doing all the fighting. Don Quixote agrees to the acrostic poem for Dulcinea.

**Chapter V: Of the Shrewd and Droll Conversation That Passed Between Sancho Panza and His Wife Teresa Panza, and Other Matters Worthy of Being Duly Recorded**
Sancho, in high spirits, tells his wife Teresa he is returning to Don Quixote's service. Teresa is confused by his roundabout speech. Sancho explains his hopes of becoming governor of an island. Teresa expresses skepticism about his ability to govern and suggests marrying their daughter Sanchica to a local boy. Sancho insists on making Sanchica a countess. Teresa worries about the social implications. Sancho argues that wealth and good conduct can elevate status. He mentions a preacher's sermon about the power of present appearances. Teresa, still skeptical, agrees to his plans but insists he take their son Sancho with him to learn governing. Sancho promises to send for his son and money. Teresa agrees to dress Sanchica finely. The translator notes Sancho's sophisticated language in this chapter.

**Chapter VI: Of What Took Place Between Don Quixote and His Niece and Housekeeper; One of the Most Important Chapters in the Whole History**
The niece and housekeeper try to dissuade Don Quixote from a third sally. Don Quixote dismisses their concerns, arguing that not all knights are courtiers, and true knights-errant endure hardships to defend kingdoms and maidens. He defends the histories of chivalry against his niece's criticisms. He explains the four types of lineages and emphasizes that virtue, wealth, and generosity make a man great. He asserts his calling to arms, guided by the planet Mars, is his destiny. The niece, amazed by his knowledge, still questions his madness. Sancho arrives, and Don Quixote and he retreat to his room.

**Chapter VII: Of What Passed Between Don Quixote and His Squire, Together with Other Very Notable Incidents**
The housekeeper, fearing another sally, rushes to Samson Carrasco for help. Carrasco, a bachelor from Salamanca, promises to intervene. Don Quixote and Sancho discuss their past adventures. Sancho complains about the beatings he received. Don Quixote explains that as his head, he suffers more in spirit for Sancho's physical pain. Don Quixote asks Sancho about the village's opinion of him. Sancho reports that common people think them mad, hidalgos criticize Don Quixote's self-proclaimed "Don," and caballeros resent his aspirations. Sancho mentions that Carrasco told him their history is in print, written by Cide Hamete Berengena (a Moor). Don Quixote believes the author is a sage enchanter. Sancho goes to fetch Carrasco.

**Chapter VIII: Wherein is Related What Befell Don Quixote on His Way to See His Lady Dulcinea del Toboso**
Don Quixote and Sancho, now alone, accept Rocinante's neighing and Dapple's sighs as good omens. Don Quixote plans to visit Dulcinea in El Toboso before any new adventures. Sancho expresses doubt about seeing her, recalling her sifting wheat in a small house. Don Quixote insists it was a palace and that enchanters distort things for him. Sancho suggests her beauty was obscured by dust. Don Quixote dismisses this, attributing it to enchanters. Sancho worries his reputation is being dragged through the dirt in the printed history. Don Quixote compares this to a poet who satirized ladies. He explains that fame is a powerful motivator, but true Christians seek eternal glory. Sancho suggests they become saints. Don Quixote agrees that there are sainted knights. They reach El Toboso at midnight.

**Chapter IX: Wherein is Related What Will Be Seen There**
Don Quixote and Sancho enter El Toboso, which is silent. Don Quixote directs Sancho to Dulcinea's palace. Sancho insists he saw her in a small house. Don Quixote believes it was a small apartment in a palace. They find the main church, which Don Quixote mistakes for a palace. Sancho complains about the difficulty of finding Dulcinea's house at night. Don Quixote reveals he has never actually seen Dulcinea, only loved her by reputation. Sancho admits he hasn't seen her either, and that his previous report of her sifting wheat was based on hearsay. Don Quixote is frustrated. They hear a laborer singing a ballad. Don Quixote asks the laborer for Dulcinea's palace, but the laborer knows of no princess. Sancho suggests they hide in a nearby forest, and he will search for Dulcinea in the daytime. Don Quixote agrees.

**Chapter X: Wherein is Related the Crafty Device Sancho Adopted to Enchant the Lady Dulcinea, and Other Incidents as Ludicrous as They Are True**
Don Quixote instructs Sancho to observe Dulcinea's reactions carefully when he delivers the message. Sancho, realizing he cannot produce a real Dulcinea, decides to trick his master. He finds three peasant girls on asses coming from El Toboso. He rushes back to Don Quixote, claiming Dulcinea and her damsels are approaching, adorned in gold and pearls, riding "piebald cackneys." Don Quixote is overjoyed and promises Sancho foals. They meet the peasant girls. Don Quixote sees only three country girls on jackasses. Sancho insists they are hackneys and that Dulcinea is shining like the sun. Don Quixote, perplexed, believes enchanters have transformed Dulcinea into a coarse peasant girl. Sancho kneels before one of the girls, proclaiming her Queen Dulcinea. The girl, annoyed, tells them to get out of the way. Don Quixote, believing his eyes are clouded by enchantment, still addresses her as Dulcinea. The girl, prodding her ass, is thrown to the ground. She quickly remounts like a man. Don Quixote, still believing in the enchantment, laments his misfortune and Dulcinea's transformation. Sancho, hiding his laughter, plays along. Don Quixote attributes Dulcinea's garlic breath to the enchanters. Sancho, in turn, claims Dulcinea has a mole with long red hairs on her lip. They resume their journey towards Saragossa.

**Chapter XI: Of the Strange Adventure Which the Valiant Don Quixote Had with the Car or Cart of “The Cortes of Death”**
Don Quixote, dejected by Dulcinea's enchantment, lets Rocinante graze freely. Sancho tries to cheer him up. Don Quixote laments his cruel fate. Sancho questions the pearl-like eyes he described for Dulcinea, suggesting they were teeth. Don Quixote agrees, attributing the confusion to enchanters. Sancho worries about how vanquished knights will recognize Dulcinea. Don Quixote suggests testing this with the first few he sends. They encounter a cart of actors dressed as characters from "The Cortés of Death," including Death, an angel, an emperor, and the devil. Don Quixote, mistaking them for a real adventure, challenges the devil-carter. The devil explains they are actors. Don Quixote, satisfied, offers his service. A merry-andrew with bells and bladders startles Rocinante, who bolts, throwing Don Quixote. The merry-andrew then jumps on Dapple and rides off. Sancho, prioritizing his master, helps Don Quixote. Dapple returns after the merry-andrew abandons him. Don Quixote wants to punish the actors, but Sancho warns against it, citing their protected status. Don Quixote, accepting Sancho's advice, lets the actors go.

**Chapter XII: Of the Strange Adventure Which Befell the Valiant Don Quixote with the Bold Knight of the Mirrors**
Don Quixote and Sancho rest under trees. Sancho expresses satisfaction with his choice of foals over the spoils of the "Death" adventure. Don Quixote regrets not taking the emperor's crown. He explains that plays are mirrors of life, and all are equal in death. Sancho agrees, citing the game of chess. Don Quixote notes Sancho's growing shrewdness. Sancho falls asleep. Don Quixote, restless, hears two men. One dismounts, and his rattling armor reveals him to be a knight-errant. Don Quixote wakes Sancho, announcing an adventure. They listen as the knight, the "Knight of the Grove," sings a love sonnet and laments his unrequited love for Casildea de Vandalia, boasting of his past victories over other knights, including Don Quixote of La Mancha. Don Quixote, enraged by the claim of his defeat, almost calls him a liar.

**Chapter XIII: In Which is Continued the Adventure of the Knight of the Grove, Together with the Sensible, Original, and Tranquil Colloquy That Passed Between the Two Squires**
The Knight of the Grove describes Don Quixote's appearance accurately, further claiming victory over him. Don Quixote, believing it to be an enchanter disguised as his friend, denies being vanquished and challenges the Knight of the Grove to a duel at daybreak. The conditions are that the vanquished will be at the victor's disposal. The squires, including Sancho, are told to prepare the horses. The Knight of the Grove's squire suggests they also fight with bags of pebbles. Sancho refuses, citing his peaceful nature and lack of a sword. He suggests they drink instead. The Knight of the Grove's squire produces wine and a large pasty. Sancho eats and drinks heartily, praising the wine and boasting of his family's wine-tasting abilities. He again expresses his desire to quit knight-errantry. The squires fall asleep. At dawn, Sancho is terrified by the Knight of the Grove's squire's enormous, hideous nose. Don Quixote, too, is amazed. Don Quixote asks the Knight of the Mirrors to raise his visor. The Knight refuses, insisting on the duel. Don Quixote, convinced he is an enchanter, prepares for battle. Sancho, fearing the nosy squire, climbs a cork tree. Don Quixote charges. The Knight of the Mirrors' horse is stuck. Don Quixote unhorses him with a powerful blow. He unlaces the helmet and sees the face of Samson Carrasco. Sancho is amazed. The squire of the Mirrors removes his false nose, revealing himself as Tom Cecial, Sancho's neighbor. Don Quixote, still believing in enchantment, demands Carrasco confess Dulcinea's beauty and go to El Toboso. Carrasco agrees. Don Quixote believes the enchanters disguised his friends.

**Chapter XIV: Wherein is Continued the Adventure of the Knight of the Grove**
This chapter is a continuation of the previous one, detailing the Knight of the Grove's (Samson Carrasco's) boasts of his love for Casildea de Vandalia and his supposed victory over Don Quixote. Don Quixote's outrage and the subsequent challenge are described.

**Chapter XV: Wherein It Is Told and Known Who the Knight of the Mirrors and His Squire Were**
Don Quixote, elated by his victory, continues his journey. The history reveals that Samson Carrasco, with the curate and barber, planned to defeat Don Quixote and force him home for a year to cure his madness. Carrasco, disguised as the Knight of the Mirrors, and Tom Cecial, disguised as his squire, set out. Their first encounter (the cart of Death) failed. In the grove, Carrasco was defeated. Tom Cecial, seeing their failure, suggests giving up. Carrasco, however, is determined to avenge his fall and continue the plan.

**Chapter XVI: Of What Befell Don Quixote with a Discreet Gentleman of La Mancha**
Don Quixote, proud of his victory, makes light of past misfortunes. He wishes to disenchant Dulcinea. Sancho still believes the Knight of the Mirrors was Carrasco and his squire Tom Cecial. Don Quixote insists it was enchantment. They meet Don Diego de Miranda, a wealthy gentleman in green. Don Quixote introduces himself as the Knight of the Lions and explains his quest to revive knight-errantry. Don Diego is amazed, finding Don Quixote a mix of madness and sense. Don Quixote then describes his vision of Dulcinea's enchantment. Don Diego, intrigued, invites them to his house. Sancho, delighted, praises Don Diego.

**Chapter XVII: Wherein is Shown the Furthest and Highest Point Which the Unexampled Courage of Don Quixote Reached or Could Reach; Together with the Happily Achieved Adventure of the Lions**
Don Quixote, preparing for a new adventure, asks Sancho for his helmet. Sancho, having bought curds, puts them in the helmet. Don Quixote puts it on, and the whey runs down his face. He believes his head is melting due to a terrible adventure. Sancho, hiding his amusement, gives him a cloth. Don Quixote, realizing it's curds, accuses Sancho. Sancho blames enchanters for putting them there. They see a cart with two caged lions, a gift for the King. Don Quixote, believing it an adventure, demands the keeper release the lions so he can fight them. Don Diego and Sancho try to dissuade him. Don Quixote insists, dismounts, and prepares to fight on foot. The keeper, under duress, opens the cage. The lion, after stretching, turns its back on Don Quixote and lies down. Don Quixote orders the keeper to provoke it, but the keeper refuses. Don Quixote, satisfied, declares victory, renames himself "the Knight of the Lions," and asks for a certificate of the event. He orders Sancho to pay the keeper and carter.

**Chapter XVIII: Of What Happened Don Quixote in the Castle or House of the Knight of the Green Gaban, Together with Other Matters Out of the Common**
Don Quixote and Sancho arrive at Don Diego's house. Don Quixote, seeing wine jars, laments Dulcinea's enchantment. Don Diego's son, Don Lorenzo, and wife, Doña Christina, are amazed by Don Quixote. Don Lorenzo, a poet, initially thinks Don Quixote sane. Don Quixote explains knight-errantry as a science encompassing many others. Don Lorenzo is impressed. Don Quixote praises poetry. Don Lorenzo recites a gloss on some verses and a sonnet on Pyramus and Thisbe. Don Quixote praises him highly. Don Quixote expresses his desire to visit the cave of Montesinos and the lakes of Ruidera. Don Diego and Don Lorenzo offer their help. Don Quixote and Sancho depart.

**Chapter XIX: In Which is Related the Adventure of the Enamoured Shepherd, Together with Other Truly Droll Incidents**
Don Quixote and Sancho meet two students and two peasants. One student tells them about the upcoming wedding of Camacho the Rich and Quiteria the Fair, and the despair of Basilio the Poor, who loves Quiteria. Don Quixote praises Basilio's skills. Sancho expresses his preference for Camacho's wealth. Don Quixote discusses the importance of parental choice in marriage. The student Corchuelo challenges the other student (the licentiate) to a fencing match. Don Quixote offers to judge. The licentiate easily defeats Corchuelo. They continue towards Quiteria's village, which is adorned for the wedding. Don Quixote insists on sleeping in the fields.

**Chapter XX: Wherein an Account is Given of the Wedding of Camacho the Rich, Together with the Incident of Basilio the Poor**
Don Quixote and Sancho wake early. Don Quixote reflects on Sancho's peaceful sleep and the burdens of masters. Sancho, smelling the wedding preparations, is eager to eat. Don Quixote urges him to witness the wedding and Basilio's actions. Sancho expresses his preference for wealth over talent. They enter the wedding arcade, filled with lavish food preparations, including a whole ox roasted. Sancho is captivated by the food and gets a bucketful of hens and geese from a cook. Dancers and a "speaking dance" performance are presented, with characters like Cupid and Interest. The dance depicts Interest breaking open the "Castle of Caution" and taking the damsel. Don Quixote comments on the dance's message. Sancho, having eaten well, declares his loyalty to Camacho. Don Quixote and Sancho debate proverbs and death.

**Chapter XXI: In Which Camacho’s Wedding is Continued, with Other Delightful Incidents**
The bride, Quiteria the Fair, arrives, richly dressed. Don Quixote thinks her beautiful, second only to Dulcinea. Basilio the Poor appears, dressed in black, and dramatically impales himself with a rapier, declaring he will die unless Quiteria gives him her hand in marriage. The priest refuses to confess him until he receives Quiteria's hand. Don Quixote declares Basilio's request just. Camacho, pressured by Basilio's friends, agrees to let Quiteria give her hand, believing it will be a symbolic gesture before his death. Quiteria, with feigned reluctance, gives her hand to Basilio, who then miraculously springs to his feet, pulling out the rapier. It is revealed he used a hollow iron tube filled with blood to feign his death. Camacho and his party are enraged, but Don Quixote intervenes, defending Basilio's trick as a legitimate stratagem in love and war. Camacho, pacified by the priest, accepts the situation. Basilio and Quiteria leave for Basilio's village, accompanied by Don Quixote and Sancho, who is sad to leave Camacho's feast.

**Chapter XXII: Wherein is Related the Grand Adventure of the Cave of Montesinos in the Heart of La Mancha, Which the Valiant Don Quixote Brought to a Happy Termination**
Don Quixote and Sancho stay with the newly married couple for three days. Don Quixote advises Basilio to pursue wealth through honest industry. Sancho makes a comment about his wife Teresa. Don Quixote then expresses a desire to visit the cave of Montesinos. The fencing licentiate offers his cousin, a scholar, as a guide. The cousin arrives, and they set out. On the way, the cousin describes his books, including "The Book of Liveries" and "Metamorphoses, or the Spanish Ovid." Sancho asks about the first man to scratch his head (Adam) and the first tumbler (Lucifer). They reach the cave of Montesinos. Don Quixote is tied with ropes and lowered into the cave. Sancho and the cousin pray for his safety.

**Chapter XXIII: Of the Wonderful Things the Incomparable Don Quixote Said He Saw in the Profound Cave of Montesinos, the Impossibility and Magnitude of Which Cause This Adventure to Be Deemed Apocryphal**
Don Quixote is pulled out of the cave, apparently asleep. He wakes, claiming to have spent three days there, seeing a beautiful meadow and a crystal palace. He met Montesinos, who confirmed the story of taking Durandarte's heart to Belerma. Durandarte, enchanted, moaned a ballad. Montesinos explained that Merlin had enchanted them all, including Guadiana (Durandarte's squire, turned into a river) and Ruidera and her daughters (turned into lakes). Montesinos also told him that Don Quixote was destined to disenchant them. Don Quixote then saw three country girls, one of whom was Dulcinea, transformed into a peasant wench. Montesinos did not recognize them. One of Dulcinea's companions asked Don Quixote for six reals, offering a dimity petticoat as a pledge. Don Quixote, having only four reals, gave them, and sent a message to Dulcinea, promising to disenchant her. Sancho, hearing this, believes his master is completely mad, as he himself had invented Dulcinea's enchantment. Don Quixote dismisses Sancho's doubts.

**Chapter XXIV: Wherein are Related a Thousand Trifling Matters, as Trivial as They Are Necessary to the Right Understanding of This Great History**
Cide Hamete, the author, expresses doubt about the truth of the Montesinos cave adventure but records it. The cousin is amazed by Don Quixote's story and Sancho's boldness. The cousin notes his own gains from the journey, including knowledge about the antiquity of cards and the source of the Guadiana. Don Quixote discusses the dedication of books. They decide to stay at an inn near a hermitage. They meet a man carrying lances and halberds, who promises to tell them curious things at the inn. They go to the inn.

**Chapter XXV: Wherein is Set Down the Braying Adventure, and the Droll One of the Puppet-Showman, Together with the Memorable Divinations of the Divining Ape**
At the inn, the man with arms tells the story of the "braying town," where two regidors (or alcaldes) brayed to find a lost ass, leading to ridicule and a planned battle between villages. A puppet-showman, Master Pedro, arrives with a divining ape and a show of "The Release of Melisendra." Don Quixote and Sancho are intrigued. The ape, through Master Pedro, answers questions about the past and present, but not the future. Master Pedro, recognizing Don Quixote and Sancho, kneels before Don Quixote, praising him as the reviver of knight-errantry. He tells Sancho that his wife Teresa is well and hackling flax. Don Quixote is amazed by the ape's divination. Sancho asks if the ape can confirm Don Quixote's cave adventure. The ape, through Master Pedro, says it's partly true, partly false. Master Pedro then sets up his puppet show.

**Chapter XXVI: Wherein is Continued the Droll Adventure of the Puppet-Showman, Together with Other Things in Truth Right Good**
The puppet show begins, narrating the story of Don Gaiferos rescuing his wife Melisendra from the Moors in Sansueña (Saragossa). The showman describes Charlemagne's anger at Don Gaiferos's inaction, Melisendra's captivity, and a Moor kissing her. Don Quixote interrupts, correcting the showman about bells not being used by Moors. The showman continues, describing Melisendra's escape and Don Gaiferos's rescue. Don Quixote, believing the puppets are real, attacks the show with his sword, destroying it and its figures. Master Pedro cries out in despair. Don Quixote justifies his actions, believing he saved Don Gaiferos and Melisendra from real Moors. Sancho is touched by Master Pedro's plight. Don Quixote agrees to pay for the damage, believing enchanters made the figures appear real. They appraise the damage. Master Pedro also asks for payment for catching his ape. Don Quixote agrees.

**Chapter XXVII: Wherein It Is Shown Who Master Pedro and His Ape Were, Together with the Mishap Don Quixote Had in the Braying Adventure, Which He Did Not Conclude as He Would Have Liked or as He Had Expected**
Cide Hamete reveals Master Pedro is Gines de Pasamonte, who stole Dapple from Sancho. Gines, to escape the Holy Brotherhood, disguised himself as a puppet-showman and used his ape to "divine" information he gathered beforehand. He recognized Don Quixote and Sancho and played a trick on them. After leaving the inn, Don Quixote and Sancho travel towards Saragossa. They encounter men from the "braying town" preparing for battle. Don Quixote tries to dissuade them with a discourse on justice and insults. Sancho, to prove his braying skill, brays loudly and is struck down. Don Quixote flees, and Sancho follows.

**Chapter XXVIII: Of Matters That Benengeli Says He Who Reads Them Will Know, If He Reads Them with Attention**
Don Quixote and Sancho retreat to a grove. Don Quixote scolds Sancho for braying. Sancho complains about his injuries and the hardships of being a squire. Don Quixote offers to pay him wages. Sancho demands a fixed monthly wage and argues that the promise of the island should count from the day it was made. Don Quixote, realizing Sancho is trying to get all his money, becomes angry and threatens to dismiss him. Sancho, remorseful, apologizes and promises to be more obedient. Don Quixote forgives him. They spend the night in the grove.

**Chapter XXIX: Of the Famous Adventure of the Enchanted Bark**
Don Quixote and Sancho reach the Ebro river. Don Quixote, still thinking of Montesinos's cave, sees a small boat without oars. He believes it is an enchanted bark calling him to an adventure. Sancho, despite his doubts, ties Rocinante and Dapple to a tree. Don Quixote and Sancho embark. Sancho is terrified as the boat drifts. Don Quixote believes they are traveling rapidly and crossing the equinoctial line. Sancho, checking for lice (a sign of crossing the line), finds none. They approach water mills, which Don Quixote mistakes for a castle. The millers, covered in flour, try to stop the boat. Don Quixote attacks them, believing them to be ruffians. The millers push the boat, throwing Don Quixote and Sancho into the water. They are rescued. The fishermen demand payment for their broken boat. Don Quixote agrees, demanding the release of the "imprisoned" person. He concludes it was an enchantment. Sancho pays for the boat.

**Chapter XXX: Of Don Quixote’s Adventure with a Fair Huntress**
Don Quixote and Sancho, dejected, continue their journey. Sancho considers leaving his master. They encounter a hawking party led by a beautiful lady (the Duchess). Don Quixote sends Sancho to present his compliments. Sancho, impressed by the Duchess's courtesy, delivers the message. The Duchess, having read the First Part of Don Quixote's history, recognizes him and invites him and Sancho to her castle. Don Quixote and Sancho are welcomed with great ceremony. Sancho, dismounting, gets his foot caught and falls. Don Quixote also falls. The Duke helps them. Don Quixote, believing himself a true knight, praises the Duchess. Sancho, comparing her beauty to Dulcinea's, causes Don Quixote to scold him. The Duke invites them to his castle.

**Chapter XXXI: Which Treats of Many and Great Matters**
Sancho is delighted to be at the Duke's castle. The Duke has instructed his servants to treat Don Quixote as a knight-errant. Don Quixote is welcomed with great pomp, including scented water. He feels truly a knight-errant. Sancho asks a duenna, Doña Rodriguez, to stable Dapple, citing the custom of ladies serving knights' hacks. Doña Rodriguez is offended. The Duchess intervenes, explaining Doña Rodriguez is young. Don Quixote scolds Sancho for his impertinence. Sancho promises to be quiet. Don Quixote is led to a richly decorated room, where damsels remove his armor. He refuses to be stripped further, citing modesty. He tells Sancho to be well-behaved. At dinner, Don Quixote is given the head of the table. Sancho tries to tell a story about seating, which irritates Don Quixote. The Duchess asks about Dulcinea. Don Quixote laments her enchantment. The ecclesiastic at the table, recognizing Don Quixote's madness, angrily reproves him. Don Quixote defends knight-errantry. The ecclesiastic leaves. Don Quixote explains that women and ecclesiastics cannot give insult. Four damsels perform a washing ceremony on Don Quixote's beard, which he endures. Sancho wishes for a similar washing. The Duchess promises it.

**Chapter XXXII: Of the Reply Don Quixote Gave His Censurer, with Other Incidents, Grave and Droll**
This chapter details Don Quixote's impassioned defense of knight-errantry against the ecclesiastic's criticisms. He argues that his calling is noble and necessary, and that he has righted wrongs. Sancho supports him. The Duke promises Sancho a government. The ecclesiastic, disgusted, leaves. Don Quixote explains the difference between "offence" and "insult." The damsels then perform a mock washing ceremony on Don Quixote, lathering his face and beard. He endures it with dignity. Sancho observes, hoping for a similar treatment.

**Chapter XXXIII: Of the Delectable Discourse Which the Duchess and Her Damsels Held with Sancho Panza, Well Worth Reading and Noting**
Sancho, after dinner, joins the Duchess and her damsels. The Duchess questions him about his deception regarding Dulcinea's enchantment. Sancho, after checking for eavesdroppers, confesses he invented the enchantment to avoid his master's anger. He tells the full story of the peasant girls. The Duchess, amused, expresses a doubt about giving a government to a "fool." Sancho defends himself with proverbs, asserting his loyalty and capacity. Doña Rodriguez, the duenna, interjects with a ballad about King Rodrigo. The Duchess reassures Sancho about the island. Sancho boasts of his governing abilities. The Duchess then insists that Dulcinea is truly enchanted, and Sancho was deceived by enchanters. Sancho, now confused, agrees. He recounts his Montesinos cave adventure. The Duchess sends Sancho to sleep, promising to arrange his government. Sancho asks for Dapple to be taken care of. The Duchess promises to put Dapple "on the apple of her eye." The Duke and Duchess plan a new trick.

**Chapter XXXIV: Which Relates How They Learned the Way in Which They Were to Disenchant the Peerless Dulcinea del Toboso, Which is One of the Rarest Adventures in This Book**
The Duke and Duchess, using Don Quixote's Montesinos story, plan a joke. Six days later, they take Don Quixote hunting. Don Quixote refuses a hunting suit, but Sancho takes one. During the boar hunt, a huge boar charges. Don Quixote and the Duke attack it. Sancho, terrified, climbs an oak, but the branch breaks, leaving him hanging upside down. He cries for help. The boar is killed. Don Quixote rescues Sancho, who laments his torn coat. Sancho complains about the dangers of hunting. The Duke defends hunting as a royal pursuit. Sancho insists a governor should stay home. As night falls, the wood seems to catch fire, and martial music and Moorish cries are heard. A postillion disguised as a demon appears, blowing a horn, and announces he is looking for Don Quixote. He delivers a message from Montesinos, saying Dulcinea is coming on a triumphal car to give instructions for her disenchantment. Sancho is terrified. Don Quixote is perplexed. Three carts appear, carrying figures of the sages Lirgandeo, Alquife, and Archelaus.

**Chapter XXXV: Wherein is Continued the Instruction Given to Don Quixote Touching the Disenchantment of Dulcinea, Together with Other Marvellous Incidents**
A triumphal car, drawn by six mules and attended by penitents, approaches. On it sits a nymph (Merlin) and a figure of Death. Merlin, in a sleepy voice, announces that Dulcinea can only be disenchanted if Sancho Panza receives 3,300 lashes on his bare buttocks. Sancho vehemently refuses, saying his backside has nothing to do with enchantments. Don Quixote threatens to whip him himself. Merlin clarifies the lashes must be voluntary or given by another (but not by force). Sancho still refuses. The nymph (Altisidora, disguised as Dulcinea) rises, removes her veil, and eloquently pleads with Sancho, describing her suffering from Don Quixote's insensibility and her transformation into a peasant. She says Don Quixote's soul is stuck in his throat. Don Quixote confirms this. Sancho still refuses the whipping. The Duke threatens to withhold his government. Sancho asks for two days to consider. Merlin insists it must be done immediately. Sancho, pressured, agrees to the lashes, on condition he can give them at his own pace, without drawing blood, and that Merlin keep count. Merlin agrees. Don Quixote embraces Sancho. The car moves, and "Dulcinea" bows to Sancho.

At dawn, the Duke and Duchess return to the castle, pleased with their trick.

**Chapter XXXVI: Wherein is Related the Strange and Undreamt-of Adventure of the Distressed Duenna, Alias the Countess Trifaldi, Together with a Letter Which Sancho Panza Wrote to His Wife, Teresa Panza**
The Duke's majordomo, who played Merlin, plans another joke. The Duchess asks Sancho about his whipping. Sancho says he gave himself five lashes with his hand. The Duchess insists on a proper scourge. Sancho agrees to use one if it doesn't hurt too much. Sancho gives the Duchess a letter he wrote to his wife, Teresa Panza, which she reads aloud. The letter describes his government, the whipping for Dulcinea, and his plans for Teresa and Sanchica. The Duchess finds Sancho covetous. A fife and drum announce the arrival of the "Distressed Duenna."

**Chapter XXXVII: Wherein is Continued the Notable Adventure of the Distressed Duenna**
Sancho expresses distrust of duennas. Don Quixote defends them. The Distressed Duenna (the majordomo in disguise) and twelve other duennas, all with veiled, bearded faces, enter the garden. The Countess Trifaldi (the majordomo) kneels before the Duke and Duchess, and asks if Don Quixote is present. Sancho confirms his presence. Don Quixote offers his aid. Trifaldi then kneels before Sancho, praising his loyalty and asking him to intercede with his master. Sancho agrees. Trifaldi begins her story: she was duenna to Princess Antonomasia of Kandy. A gentleman, Don Clavijo, seduced the princess with her (Trifaldi's) help. The princess became pregnant. Don Clavijo married her secretly. Queen Maguncia (the princess's mother) died of grief. The giant Malambruno, the queen's cousin and an enchanter, appeared on a wooden horse, enchanting Don Clavijo into a crocodile and Antonomasia into a brass ape. He then punished the duennas by covering their faces with beards.

**Chapter XXXVIII: Wherein is Told the Distressed Duenna’s Tale of Her Misfortunes**
This chapter continues Trifaldi's story, detailing the enchantment of Princess Antonomasia and Don Clavijo, and the bearding of the duennas by Malambruno. The duennas reveal their bearded faces, astonishing everyone. Trifaldi laments their fate. Sancho is moved and promises to help. Trifaldi explains that Malambruno will send a wooden horse, Clavileño the Swift, which flies through the air, to transport Don Quixote and Sancho to Kandy to fight Malambruno. Sancho is reluctant to ride the horse, fearing heights and the long journey, and insists he cannot help with the shaving of beards. The Duke reassures him about his promised island. Sancho agrees to go.

**Chapter XXXIX: In Which the Trifaldi Continues Her Marvellous and Memorable Story**
This chapter is a continuation of Trifaldi's story. She explains that the wooden horse, Clavileño, will arrive shortly. Sancho asks about the horse's name and how it is controlled. Trifaldi explains it is controlled by a peg in its forehead. Sancho again expresses his reluctance to ride, but the Duke and Duchess persuade him, promising his island. Don Quixote and Sancho are blindfolded and mounted on Clavileño. The Duke's servants use bellows and tow to simulate wind and fire, making them believe they are flying. Sancho peeks and claims to see the earth as a mustard seed and men as hazelnuts, and that he visited the "seven goats" in heaven. Don Quixote dismisses this as a dream or enchantment. The horse explodes, throwing them to the ground. They find themselves back in the garden. A placard announces that Don Quixote, by merely attempting the adventure, has disenchanted the duennas and the princess and Don Clavijo. Sancho is still confused about his celestial journey.

**Chapter XL: Of Matters Relating and Belonging to This Adventure and to This Memorable History**
This chapter is a continuation of the previous one, detailing the arrival of Clavileño, the mock flight, and the "disenchantment" of the duennas. Don Quixote and Sancho are thrown to the ground. A placard announces the success of the adventure and the disenchantment of the duennas, Princess Antonomasia, and Don Clavijo. Sancho claims to have seen the earth from above and visited the "seven goats" in heaven. Don Quixote dismisses Sancho's claims.

**Chapter XLI: Of the Arrival of Clavileño and the End of This Protracted Adventure**
This chapter is a continuation of the previous one, detailing the "arrival" of Clavileño, the mock flight, and the "disenchantment" of the duennas. Don Quixote and Sancho are thrown to the ground. A placard announces the success of the adventure and the disenchantment of the duennas, Princess Antonomasia, and Don Clavijo. Sancho claims to have seen the earth from above and visited the "seven goats" in heaven. Don Quixote dismisses Sancho's claims.

**Chapter XLII: Of the Counsels Which Don Quixote Gave Sancho Panza Before He Set Out to Govern the Island, Together with Other Well-Considered Matters**
The Duke and Duchess, pleased with the Clavileño joke, decide to proceed with Sancho's government. The Duke tells Sancho to prepare. Sancho expresses reduced enthusiasm for governing after seeing the smallness of the earth from "heaven." The Duke reassures him it's a real island. Don Quixote gives Sancho detailed advice on how to govern, emphasizing fear of God, self-knowledge, humility, virtue, justice, and mercy. He advises him on personal conduct: cleanliness, proper dress, temperance in eating and drinking, and avoiding excessive proverbs. Sancho, overwhelmed, asks for the advice in writing. Don Quixote notes the importance of literacy for governors and advises Sancho to learn to sign his name. Sancho, using proverbs, insists he is capable. Don Quixote, frustrated by Sancho's proverbs, threatens to dismiss him. Sancho, remorseful, apologizes. They go to dinner.

**Chapter XLIII: Of the Second Set of Counsels Don Quixote Gave Sancho Panza**
This chapter continues Don Quixote's advice to Sancho on governing. He advises on personal hygiene, dress, eating, drinking, and speech. He tells Sancho not to use too many proverbs. He also advises on riding, sleep, and avoiding disputes about family lineages. Sancho, overwhelmed, asks for the advice in writing. Don Quixote scolds him for being illiterate but tells him to learn to sign his name. Sancho, using more proverbs, insists he is capable. Don Quixote, frustrated, threatens to dismiss him. Sancho, remorseful, apologizes.

**Chapter XLIV: How Sancho Panza Was Conducted to His Government, and of the Strange Adventure That Befell Don Quixote in the Castle**
Cide Hamete, the author, explains his decision to focus on Don Quixote and Sancho, avoiding extraneous novels in this part. Sancho is dispatched to his government, accompanied by the Duke's majordomo (the disguised Trifaldi). Sancho recognizes the majordomo's face but dismisses it as enchantment. Sancho, dressed as a lawyer, rides a mule, with Dapple following. He is delighted. Don Quixote feels lonely after Sancho's departure. The Duchess offers him other squires. Don Quixote, fearing temptations, insists on being alone in his room. The Duchess agrees. Don Quixote undresses and discovers a large tear in his green stockings. He laments his poverty. He opens his window and hears two damsels, Altisidora and Emerencia, singing a love ballad for him. Don Quixote, believing Altisidora is in love with him, resolves to remain faithful to Dulcinea.

**Chapter XLV: Of How the Great Sancho Panza Took Possession of His Island, and of How He Made a Beginning in Governing**
Sancho arrives at the village of Barataria, welcomed with pomp and bells. He is acknowledged as governor. He is seated at a judgment seat. He learns the village is called Barataria. He insists his name is plain Sancho Panza, without "Don." He is presented with a difficult case: two old men disputing a loan. Sancho discovers the money is hidden in the cane of the debtor. He orders the cane broken, revealing the gold crowns. Everyone is amazed. Next, a woman accuses a pig dealer of rape. Sancho orders the dealer to give her his money. When she runs off, he orders the dealer to take it back. She fiercely defends the purse. Sancho, realizing her strength, rules that she should have defended her body with the same vigor. He returns the money to the man and banishes the woman. Then, a tailor and a laborer dispute over five caps made from one piece of cloth. Sancho rules that the tailor loses the making, the laborer the cloth, and the caps go to the prisoners. Sancho's judgments are sent to the Duke.

**Chapter XLVI: Of the Terrible Bell and Cat Fright That Don Quixote Got in the Course of the Enamoured Altisidora’s Wooing**
Don Quixote, troubled by Altisidora's song, goes to bed. At dawn, he dresses and goes to the antechamber. Altisidora pretends to faint, and her friend blames Don Quixote's insensibility. Don Quixote, believing it's a love sickness, offers to sing for her. The Duchess and Duke plan a prank. That night, Don Quixote finds a guitar in his room. He sings a ballad about constancy in love, declaring his fidelity to Dulcinea. Suddenly, a cord with bells and a sack of cats is dropped from a gallery above his window. Cats enter his room, extinguishing candles. Don Quixote, believing them enchanters, fights them with his sword. A cat clings to his nose. The Duke and Duchess rush in and remove the cat. Don Quixote's face is scratched. Altisidora bandages him, blaming his cruelty for her "death." Don Quixote, though vexed, thanks them.

**Chapter XLVII: Wherein is Continued the Account of How Sancho Panza Conducted Himself in His Government**
Sancho is taken to a palace for dinner. A physician, Doctor Pedro Recio de Aguero, stands by, restricting Sancho's food intake based on Hippocratic aphorisms. Sancho, starving, curses the doctor and demands food. A courier arrives with a letter from the Duke, warning of spies and assassins. Sancho orders the doctor imprisoned and demands bread and grapes. He dictates a letter to Don Quixote, complaining about the doctor and his hunger, and asking for his wife's letter to be sent. A farmer arrives with a strange request: he wants a letter of recommendation for his son to marry a girl with many physical deformities, and also asks for 600 ducats. Sancho, enraged, threatens the farmer. The farmer, who is part of the joke, retreats.

**Chapter XLVIII: Of What Befell Don Quixote with Doña Rodriguez, the Duchess’s Duenna, Together with Other Occurrences Worthy of Record and Eternal Remembrance**
Don Quixote, recovering from his cat scratches, is restless. Doña Rodriguez, the duenna, enters his room at night. Don Quixote, fearing another amorous assault, declares his fidelity to Dulcinea. Doña Rodriguez, terrified by his appearance, drops her candle. Don Quixote, believing her a phantom, conjures her. She reveals she is Doña Rodriguez, the duenna, and has a grievance. Don Quixote, wary of love messages, tells her to light her candle and return. He reflects on the dangers of duennas. Doña Rodriguez returns and tells her story: she is a noble Asturian, but her parents' poverty led her to service. She married an esquire, who died. Her daughter was seduced by a rich farmer's son, who refuses to marry her. She asks Don Quixote to challenge the farmer. She also reveals that the Duchess has "issues" (drains) on her legs. Don Quixote is amazed. Suddenly, the door bursts open, the candle is extinguished, and two hands seize Doña Rodriguez, beating her. Don Quixote is also pinched and stripped. The attackers flee. Don Quixote is left sore and puzzled.

**Chapter XLIX: Of What Happened Sancho in Making the Round of His Island**
Sancho, still governor, complains about the importunities of applicants. Doctor Pedro Recio promises him supper. Sancho eats heartily, declaring his preference for simple food and his intention to govern justly and purge the island of idlers. He goes on a night round with his retinue. They hear a clash of swords. Two men are fighting over gambling winnings. Sancho orders the winner to give the loser 100 reals and 30 for prisoners, and banishes the loser for ten years. Next, a young man is caught running from officers. He claims he was taking the air. Sancho, finding his answers facetious, orders him to jail. The young man argues that Sancho cannot make him sleep if he chooses to stay awake. Sancho, convinced, lets him go. Two tipstaffs bring a young woman disguised as a man. She confesses she is the daughter of Diego de la Llana, who keeps her secluded. She and her brother dressed as men to see the town at night. Sancho, after hearing her story, sends them home. The head-carver falls in love with the girl. Sancho considers marrying the youth to his daughter Sanchica.

**Chapter L: Wherein is Set Forth Who the Enchanters and Executioners Were Who Flogged the Duenna and Pinched Don Quixote, and Also What Befell the Page Who Carried the Letter to Teresa Panza, Sancho Panza’s Wife**
The duenna who slept with Doña Rodriguez reported her visit to Don Quixote to the Duchess. The Duchess and Altisidora, enraged by Doña Rodriguez's revelations about the Duchess's "issues," burst into Don Quixote's room and flogged Doña Rodriguez and pinched Don Quixote. The Duchess then sends the page (who played Dulcinea in the disenchantment prank) to Teresa Panza with Sancho's letter and a present. The page meets Sanchica, who leads him to Teresa. Teresa is overjoyed by the news of Sancho's governorship and the presents. She asks the page to read the letters. The letters confirm Sancho's governorship and the Duchess's kindness. Teresa and Sanchica are excited about their new status. Teresa plans to go to Court in a coach. The page explains the Duchess's humility and that Sancho's government is real. The curate and bachelor are still skeptical. The page eats with them. Teresa dictates two letters, one to Sancho and one to the Duchess, expressing her joy and giving village news. The Duke and Duchess are amused by Teresa's letters.

**Chapter LI: Of the Progress of Sancho’s Government, and Other Such Entertaining Matters**
Sancho, still governor, endures hunger due to Doctor Pedro Recio's diet. He hears a complex case about a man who swore to die on a gallows if he crossed a bridge. Sancho rules that the man should be allowed to pass, leaning towards mercy. He receives a letter from Don Quixote, advising him on governing, dress, and conduct. Don Quixote also mentions his cat scratches and Dulcinea's enchantment. Sancho replies, complaining about hunger and the doctor, and confirming his intention to govern justly. He mentions his plans for his daughter and the disguised damsel. He makes several ordinances for his island.

**Chapter LII: Wherein is Related the Adventure of the Second Distressed or Afflicted Duenna, Otherwise Called Doña Rodriguez**
Don Quixote, recovered from his scratches, plans to leave the castle for Saragossa. Doña Rodriguez and her daughter appear, draped in mourning. Doña Rodriguez kneels before Don Quixote, reminding him of his promise to help her daughter, who was seduced by a rich farmer's son. She asks Don Quixote to challenge the farmer. Don Quixote agrees. The Duke offers to arrange the combat at the castle. Don Quixote throws down his glove as a challenge. The Duke sets the terms. Doña Rodriguez and her daughter formally place their claim in Don Quixote's hands. The page returns with letters from Teresa Panza. Teresa's letter to the Duchess expresses her joy and requests money for a coach. Her letter to Sancho expresses similar sentiments and village news. The Duke and Duchess are amused.

**Chapter LIII: Of the Troublous End and Termination Sancho Panza’s Government Came To**
On the seventh night of his government, Sancho is awakened by a great noise of bells and shouting. A band of men with torches and swords rush into his room, shouting that the island is under attack. They arm Sancho with two shields, one front and one back, binding him tightly so he cannot move. They place a lance in his hand and order him to lead them. Sancho, unable to move, falls to the ground. The men trample him, shouting orders. Sancho, bruised and terrified, prays for the island to be lost. Suddenly, the men shout "Victory!" and lift Sancho up. Sancho, parched with thirst, asks for wine. They rub him down and give him wine. He faints. When he recovers, he asks the time. He then dresses and goes to Dapple, embracing him and lamenting his brief, troublesome government. He declares he was not born to be a governor and prefers his old freedom. He tells the majordomo to inform the Duke that he leaves the government as he found it, without profit. Doctor Recio tries to persuade him to stay. Sancho refuses, saying he is of the "Panzas" breed, who are obstinate. He leaves the "ant's wings" (his ambition) behind and departs on Dapple, taking only his half cheese and half loaf.

**Chapter LIV: Which Deals with Matters Relating to This History and No Other**
The Duke and Duchess decide to proceed with the challenge for Doña Rodriguez's daughter, substituting their lacquey Tosilos for the farmer. Don Quixote is pleased. Sancho, on his way to rejoin Don Quixote, meets six pilgrims. One of them, Ricote, recognizes Sancho and reveals he is a Morisco from Sancho's village, returning to retrieve buried treasure. Ricote explains the expulsion of the Moriscos and his journey through Europe. He offers Sancho 200 crowns to help him. Sancho refuses, citing his loyalty to the King and his recent resignation from governorship. Ricote is surprised by Sancho's governorship. Sancho explains his brief, difficult experience. Ricote asks about his daughter, Ana Felix. Sancho describes her beauty and how Don Pedro Gregorio was in love with her. Ricote and Sancho part ways.

**Chapter LV: Of What Befell Sancho on the Road, and Other Things That Cannot Be Surpassed**
Sancho, delayed by Ricote, is caught by night near the Duke's castle. He and Dapple fall into a deep pit. Sancho, unharmed, laments his misfortune and compares it to Don Quixote's pleasant experience in Montesinos's cave. He finds a small opening and enlarges it for Dapple. He explores the cavern. Meanwhile, Don Quixote, preparing for the combat, almost falls into the same pit. He hears Sancho's cries and recognizes his voice. Don Quixote believes Sancho's soul is in torment. Sancho assures him he is alive. Don Quixote goes to the castle for help. The Duke and Duchess are surprised by Sancho's fall and his resignation from government. They send ropes and rescue Sancho and Dapple. Sancho, bruised, complains about his government. Don Quixote consoles him.

**Chapter LVI: Of the Prodigious and Unparalleled Battle That Took Place Between Don Quixote of La Mancha and the Lacquey Tosilos in Defence of the Daughter of Doña Rodriguez**
The Duke and Duchess are amused by Sancho's account of his government. The day of the combat arrives. The Duke instructs Tosilos, his lacquey, to defeat Don Quixote without harming him. The lances are blunted. Tosilos, on a Friesland horse, enters the lists. Don Quixote, in full armor, also enters. The duennas, mother and daughter, are present. The conditions are stated: if Don Quixote wins, Tosilos marries the daughter; if he loses, he is free. The signal is given. Tosilos, however, is smitten by Doña Rodriguez's daughter and, overcome by love, declares himself vanquished and agrees to marry her. Don Quixote, seeing his opponent not charging, pulls up. The Duke is angry. Tosilos approaches the duennas and reaffirms his intention to marry. Don Quixote declares himself released from his promise. Tosilos's helmet is removed, revealing him as the lacquey. Doña Rodriguez and her daughter cry out, realizing the trick. Don Quixote, believing it's enchantment, urges them to marry him anyway. The Duke suggests a fortnight's delay to see if the enchantment wears off. Sancho insists Tosilos will remain a lacquey. The daughter accepts Tosilos as her husband. Tosilos is confined. Don Quixote is hailed as victor.

**Chapter LVII: Which Treats of How Don Quixote Took Leave of the Duke, and of What Followed with the Witty and Impudent Altisidora, One of the Duchess’s Damsels**
Don Quixote decides to leave the castle, feeling his idleness is inappropriate for a knight-errant. The Duke and Duchess grant his request. Sancho receives Teresa's letters and 200 gold crowns from the majordomo. Sancho is happy, reflecting on his "naked" entry and exit from government. Don Quixote, fully armored, appears in the courtyard. Altisidora, the Duchess's damsel, sings a farewell lament, accusing Don Quixote of cruelty and theft (three kerchiefs and garters). Don Quixote denies the theft of garters but admits Sancho has the kerchiefs. The Duke, playing along, also accuses Don Quixote. Don Quixote denies being a thief and attributes Altisidora's passion to love. The Duchess promises to chastise Altisidora. Altisidora admits she has the garters. Don Quixote and Sancho depart for Saragossa.

**Chapter LVIII: Which Tells How Adventures Came Crowding on Don Quixote in Such Numbers That They Gave One Another No Breathing-Time**
Don Quixote, feeling free, reflects on the value of freedom. Sancho, pleased with his 200 crowns, still values his master. They encounter a group of laborers carrying images for a retablo. Don Quixote asks to see them. He identifies Saint George, Saint Martin, and Saint James the Moorslayer, and Saint Paul. He compares them to knights-errant and laments his own sinful state, hoping Dulcinea's disenchantment will lead him to a better path. Sancho is amazed by his master's knowledge. Don Quixote explains that omens are merely accidents. Sancho asks about the Spanish battle cry "Santiago and close Spain!" Don Quixote explains its origin. Sancho then questions Altisidora's love for Don Quixote, given his lack of beauty. Don Quixote explains the two sorts of beauty (mind and body). They ride into a wood and are caught in green nets. Two shepherdesses (ladies in disguise) appear, explaining the nets are for their pastoral amusement. Don Quixote is captivated and offers his service. Sancho recognizes them. Don Quixote, despite being invited to stay, insists on continuing his quest. He declares he will maintain that these shepherdesses are the fairest in the world, second only to Dulcinea. Sancho, delighted, supports him. Don Quixote posts himself on the highway, making his challenge. A drove of bulls and herdsmen stampedes over Don Quixote, Sancho, Rocinante, and Dapple. They are left bruised and humiliated.

**Chapter LIX: Wherein is Related the Strange Thing, Which May Be Regarded as an Adventure, That Happened Don Quixote**
Don Quixote and Sancho rest by a spring. Don Quixote, dejected by his defeat by the bulls, refuses to eat. Sancho, eating heartily, advises him to sleep. Don Quixote asks Sancho to give himself 300-400 lashes for Dulcinea's disenchantment. Sancho agrees to do it later. They sleep and then head for an inn. Don Quixote, now more rational, recognizes it as an inn. At supper, they overhear two gentlemen reading a "Second Part of Don Quixote," which they criticize, especially for its portrayal of Don Quixote and Sancho, and for changing Sancho's wife's name to Mari Gutierrez. Don Quixote, enraged, confronts them, declaring himself the true Don Quixote. The gentlemen are amazed. Sancho also defends his identity. Don Quixote refuses to read the false history. He decides to go to Barcelona instead of Saragossa to expose the false author.

**Chapter LX: Of What Happened Don Quixote on His Way to Barcelona**
Don Quixote and Sancho travel towards Barcelona, avoiding Saragossa. Don Quixote, unable to sleep, reflects on Dulcinea's enchantment and Sancho's slow progress with the lashes. He considers forcing Sancho to whip himself. He approaches Sancho, who wakes and resists, tripping Don Quixote and pinning him down. Don Quixote promises not to whip him. Sancho then discovers men's feet hanging from trees, which Don Quixote identifies as hanged freebooters, indicating they are near Barcelona. They are then surrounded by forty living freebooters, led by Roque Guinart. The robbers strip Dapple of his belongings, but Sancho's money belt is spared. Roque Guinart, recognizing Don Quixote's madness, is intrigued. A young woman, Claudia Jeronima, disguised as a man, arrives, seeking Roque's help. She confesses to shooting her lover, Don Vicente, for his treachery. Roque and Claudia go to find Don Vicente, who is dying. Don Vicente denies treachery. Claudia faints, and Don Vicente dies. Claudia resolves to go to a convent. Roque Guinart returns to his men, who complain about his generosity. Roque distributes spoils fairly. He writes a letter to a friend in Barcelona, announcing Don Quixote's arrival.

**Chapter LXI: Of What Happened Don Quixote on Entering Barcelona, Together with Other Matters That Partake of the True Rather Than of the Ingenious**
Don Quixote spends three days with Roque Guinart, observing his life as a bandit. Roque, Don Quixote, and Sancho travel to Barcelona. They reach the beach on Saint John's Eve. Roque gives Sancho the promised ten crowns and departs. At dawn, they witness a naval display with galleys and horsemen. Don Quixote is amazed by the sea. A cavalier, Don Antonio Moreno, welcomes Don Quixote, having read his history. Don Quixote and Sancho are led into the city. Boys play a prank, inserting furze under Rocinante's and Dapple's tails, causing them to buck and throw their masters. Don Quixote and Sancho are humiliated but remount and reach Don Antonio's house.

**Chapter LXII: Which Deals with the Adventure of the Enchanted Head, Together with Other Trivial Matters Which Cannot Be Left Untold**
Don Antonio Moreno, Don Quixote's host, plans harmless jokes. He takes Don Quixote, in his chamois suit, onto a balcony to be seen by the crowd. Don Quixote is honored. At dinner, Don Antonio teases Sancho about his eating habits. Sancho defends his cleanliness and recounts his governorship. Don Quixote is amused. Don Antonio takes Don Quixote to a private room to show him an "enchanted head" that answers questions. He explains it was made by a Polish magician and will work tomorrow. Don Quixote is amazed. Don Antonio takes Don Quixote for a stroll, secretly stitching a placard "This is Don Quixote of La Mancha" on his back. People recognize him, and one Castilian scolds him for his madness. Don Antonio removes the placard. That night, at a dancing party, Don Quixote is tired out by two mischievous ladies who make "secret love" to him. He repels them, declaring his fidelity to Dulcinea, and collapses. Sancho carries him to bed. The next day, Don Antonio tests the enchanted head with Don Quixote, Sancho, and others. The head answers questions about thoughts, numbers present, and personal matters. It tells Don Quixote his cave adventure was partly true, partly false, and that Sancho's whipping will proceed. It tells Sancho he will govern in his house and see his family. Don Antonio reveals the head is a trick, operated by his nephew through a tube. Don Quixote and Sancho still believe it's enchanted. Don Quixote visits a printing office, where he sees a "Second Part of Don Quixote" by a new author, which he criticizes. He decides not to go to Saragossa.

**Chapter LXIII: Of the Mishap That Befell Sancho Panza Through the Visit to the Galleys, and the Strange Adventure of the Fair Morisco**
Don Quixote reflects on the enchanted head's prophecy. Don Antonio takes Don Quixote and Sancho to see the galleys. They are received with great ceremony. Sancho is subjected to a "ceremony" where he is tossed along the benches by the crew. Don Quixote is enraged. The general orders the galleys to pursue an oared vessel. They capture it. The general discovers the rais (captain) is a young, beautiful woman who claims to be a Christian. She tells her story: she is a Morisco, Ana Felix, who was forced to Barbary with her uncles. She fell in love with Don Gaspar Gregorio, who disguised himself as a woman to be with her. She returned to Spain to retrieve buried treasure, accompanied by two Turks and a renegade. The Turks killed two soldiers. Ricote, Ana Felix's father, appears, having returned from Germany to find his daughter and treasure. He is reunited with Ana Felix. The viceroy, moved, spares Ana Felix. They plan to rescue Don Gaspar Gregorio.

**Chapter LXIV: Treating of the Adventure Which Gave Don Quixote More Unhappiness Than All That Had Hitherto Befallen Him**
Don Quixote advises against the rescue plan for Don Gregorio, suggesting he go to Barbary himself. Sancho is skeptical. The renegade sets sail. Don Quixote, walking on the beach, is challenged by the Knight of the White Moon. The Knight demands Don Quixote confess his lady is fairer than Dulcinea, or fight. If Don Quixote loses, he must return home for a year and give up knight-errantry. Don Quixote accepts the challenge. The viceroy, present, allows the combat. The two knights charge. The Knight of the White Moon unhorses Don Quixote. Don Quixote, bruised, confesses Dulcinea is the fairest but refuses to give up his honor. The Knight of the White Moon insists on the year-long retirement. Don Quixote agrees. The Knight of the White Moon rides off. Don Quixote is carried back to the city, dejected.

**Chapter LXV: Wherein is Made Known Who the Knight of the White Moon Was; Likewise Don Gregorio’s Release, and Other Events**
